nexttext:
We show in ${\textrm{ZFC}}$ that
 $\Phi(\kappa,\omega,\omega)$ is true
 iff $\kappa < {\mathfrak}{b}$,
 where ${\mathfrak}{b}$ is the \textit{bounding number}.
Also in ${\textrm{ZFC}}$,
 $\Phi(\omega_1,\omega_1,\omega)$ is false.
However, assuming ${\textrm{ZF}} + {\textrm{AD}}$ we have that
 $\Phi(\omega_1, \omega_1, \omega)$ is true
 (and we would like to show that
 $\Phi(\lambda_1, \lambda_2, \mu)$ is true
 whenever $\mu \le \lambda_1 \le \lambda_2 < \Theta$).
\end{abstract}

\maketitle

For sets $\lambda_1, \lambda_2$

 that whenever $f : \lambda_1 \times \lambda_2 \to \mu$,

nexttext:
We will usually consider the case when
 $\lambda_1$ and $\lambda_2$ are cardinals.
When this happens,
 without loss of generality
 $\mu$ is regular and
 $\lambda_1, \lambda_2 \ge \mu$.

Note that if $\lambda_1 \le \lambda_1'$
 and $\lambda_2 \le \lambda_2'$, then
 $\Phi(\lambda_1', \lambda_2', \mu)$ implies
 $\Phi(\lambda_1, \lambda_2, \mu)$.
Here is a positive result.
\begin{proposition}
(${\textrm{ZF}}$)
Let $\mu$ be an infinite regular cardinal.
Then $\Phi(\mu, \mu, \mu)$ is true.
\end{proposition}
\begin{proof}
Fix $f : \mu \times \mu \to \mu$.
Let $g_2 : \mu \to \mu$ be such that
 for each $x \in \mu$,
 the set
 $S_x := \{ y < \mu : f(x,y) > g_2(y)\}$
 has size $< \mu$.
That is, $g_2$ eventually dominates
 the functions of the form
 $y \mapsto f(x,y)$.
Let $g_1 : \mu \to \mu$ be such that
 for each $x \in \mu$,
 $g_1(x) \ge \sup \{ f(x,y) : y \in S_x \}$.
The functions $g_1$ and $g_2$ work.
\end{proof}

Let $\mu$ be an infinite regular cardinal.
Recall that ${\mathfrak}{b}(\mu)$,
 the \textit{bounding number for} $\mu$,
 is the smallest size of a family
 ${\mathcal}{F} \subseteq {^\mu \mu}$
 that cannot be eventually-dominated
 (mod $<\mu$) by a single function
 from $\mu$ to $\mu$.
Without the Axoim of Choice,
 we interpret ``$\lambda < {\mathfrak}{b}(\mu)$''
 as meaning that every size $\lambda$
 family ${\mathcal}{F} \subseteq {^\mu \mu}$
 can be eventually-dominated,
 and ``$\lambda \ge {\mathfrak}{b}(\mu)$''
 as meaning that there is some
 size $\lambda$ family that cannot
 be eventually-dominated.
The following is an improvement
 of the proposition above:

\begin{proposition}
(${\textrm{ZF}}$)
Let $\mu$ be an infinite regular cardinal.
Let $\lambda_1 < {\mathfrak}{b}(\mu)$.
Then $\Phi(\lambda_1, \mu, \mu)$ is true.
\end{proposition}
\begin{proof}
Fix $f : \lambda_1 \times \mu \to \mu$.
Let $g_2 : \mu \to \mu$ be such that
 for each $x \in \lambda_1$, the set
 $S_x := \{ y < \mu : f(x,y) > g_2(y) \}$
 has size $< \mu$.
The function $g_2$ exists because
 $\lambda_1 < {\mathfrak}{b}(\mu)$.
Like before, we let $g_1 : \lambda_1 \to \mu$
 be such that for each $x \in \lambda_1$,
 $g_1(x) \ge \sup \{ f(x,y) : y \in S_x \}$.
\end{proof}

\begin{proposition}
(${\textrm{ZF}}$)
Let $\mu$ be an infinite regular cardinal.
Let $\lambda_1 \ge {\mathfrak}{b}(\mu)$.
Then $\Phi(\lambda_1, \mu, \mu)$ fails.
\end{proposition}
\begin{proof}
Let $f : \lambda_1 \times \mu \to \mu$
 be such that the functions of the form
 $y \mapsto f(x,y)$ cannot be
 eventually dominated by a single
 function from $\mu$ to $\mu$.
By possibly increasing the values
 of the function $f$,
 we may assume that whenever
 $x \in \lambda_1$ and
 $Y \in [\mu]^\mu$,
 the set $f`` \{x\} \times Y$
 is unbounded below $\mu$.
Now, consider any $g_2 : \mu \to \mu$.
By hypothesis, fix some
 $x \in \lambda_1$ such that
 $g_2$ does not eventually dominate
 the function $y \mapsto f(x,y)$.
That is,
 $S_x := \{ y < \mu :
 f(x,y) > g_2(y) \}$ is in $[\mu]^\mu$,
 so $f`` \{x\} \times S_x$
 is unbounded below $\mu$.
Hence, there is no $\alpha < \mu$ such that
 for all $y < \mu$,
prevtext:

However, assuming ${\textrm{ZF}} + {\textrm{AD}}$ we have that
 $\Phi(\omega_1, \omega_1, \omega)$ is true
 (and we would like to show that
 $\Phi(\lambda_1, \lambda_2, \mu)$ is true
 whenever $\mu \le \lambda_1 \le \lambda_2 < \Theta$).
\end{abstract}

 $X := g_1^{-1}(\alpha) \in {\mathcal}{I}^+$.
Let $y \in \lambda_2$ be such that

There is a function $f : \omega_1 \times {\mathbb}{R} \to \omega$

To show other instances in which
 $\Phi(\lambda_1, \lambda_2, \mu)$ fails,
 the following is useful:

\begin{lemma}
\label{ideal_lemma}
(${\textrm{ZF}}$)
If $f : \lambda_1 \times \lambda_2 \to \mu$ is such that
 there is a $\mu^+$-complete ideal ${\mathcal}{I}$ on $\lambda_1$
 and every $X \in {\mathcal}{I}^+$ has a corresponding
 $y \in \lambda_2$ such that
 $f`` X \times \{y\}$ is unbounded below $\mu$,
 then $f$ witnesses that
 $\neg \Phi(\lambda_1, \lambda_2, \mu)$.
\end{lemma}
\begin{proof}
Suppose we have such an $f$.
Pick any $g_1 : \lambda_1 \to \mu$.
Let $\alpha < \mu$ be such that
 $X := g_1^{-1}(\alpha) \in {\mathcal}{I}^+$.
Let $y \in \lambda_2$ be such that
 $f `` X \times \{y\}$ is unbounded below $\mu$.
There must be some $x \in X$ such that

nexttext:
\end{lemma}
\begin{proof}
We will build an $f$ so that in fact
 for each $X \in [\omega_1]^\omega$ and
 $g : X \to \omega$,
 there is an $r \in {\mathbb}{R}$ such that
 $(\forall x \in X)\, f(x,r) = g(x)$.
Given any $r \in {\mathbb}{R}$,
 let $\langle x^r_0, x^r_1, ..., y^r_0, y^r_1, ... \rangle
 \in {^\omega {\mathbb}{R}} \times {^\omega \omega}$
 be the $(\omega+\omega)$-sequence of
 reals and natural numbers canonically coded by $r$.
Let $\eta : {\mathbb}{R} \to \omega_1$ be a surjection.
If $\eta(x) = \alpha$, say that $x$ is a \textit{code} for $\alpha$.
Define $f$ as follows:
 let $f(\alpha,r) := y^r_n$ if $x^r_n$ is a code for $\alpha$
 and no $x^r_m$ for $m < n$ is a code for $\alpha$,
 and let $f(\alpha,r) := 0$ if there is no such $x^r_n$.
The function $f$ is as desired:
 given $\{x_0, ...\} \in [\omega_1]^\omega$
 and $g : X \to \omega$,
 simply choose $r \in {\mathbb}{R}$ so that
 $(\forall n \in \omega)\, x^r_n = x_n$ and $y^r_n = g(x_n)$.
\end{proof}
\begin{cor}
(ZF) $\neg \Phi( \omega_1, {\mathbb}{R}, \omega )$,
 and therefore also
 $\neg \Phi( {\mathbb}{R}, {\mathbb}{R}, \omega )$.
\end{cor}

Here is another way to get an $f$
 satisfying the hypothesis of Lemma~\ref{ideal_lemma}:
\begin{lemma}
\label{almost_disjoint_family}
(${\textrm{ZFC}}$)
There is a function $f : \omega_1 \times \omega_1 \to \omega$
 such that for each $\{x_1, x_2\} \in [\omega_1]^2$,
 $\{ \alpha < \omega_1 : f(x_1,\alpha) = f(x_2,\alpha)\}$
 has size $< \omega_1$.
That is, the collection of functions of the form
 $y \mapsto f(x,y)$ is an almost disjoint family.
\end{lemma}
\begin{proof}
For each $\alpha < \omega_1$, define the values
 $f(\beta, \alpha) : \beta < \alpha$ to be distinct by
 choosing a bijection from $\omega$ to $\alpha$.
The values $f(\beta,\alpha)$ for $\beta \ge \alpha$
 can be chosen to be anything.
\end{proof}

We now have the following:
\begin{cor}
(${\textrm{ZFC}}$)
$\Phi(\omega_1, \omega_1, \omega)$ is false.
\end{cor}
\begin{proof}
Use the function $f$ from Lemma~\ref{almost_disjoint_family}.
For each $X \in [\omega_1]^\omega$,
 ${\mathcal}{F}_X := \{ y \mapsto f(x,y) : x \in X\}$ is unbounded.
Therefore for each $X \in [\omega_1]^{\omega_1}$,
 ${\mathcal}{F}_X$ is unbounded.
The collection $[\omega_1]^{\omega_1}$ is the same thing
 as ${\mathcal}{I}^+$ where ${\mathcal}{I}$ is the $\omega^+$-complete
 ideal $[\omega_1]^\omega$ on $\omega_1$.
Thus, we may use
Lemma~\ref{ideal_lemma} with $f$ and ${\mathcal}{I}$.
\end{proof}

\section{Lowerbound}

Note that Lemma~\ref{almost_disjoint_family} is satisfied
 in ${\textrm{ZF}}$ if there is a function
 $f : \omega_1 \to {\mathcal{P}}(\omega)$ that maps each
 $\alpha < \omega_1$ to a code $f(\alpha)$ for
 a well-ordering of ordertype $\alpha$.
This happens, for example,
 if there is an $r \in {\mathbb}{R}$ such that
 $\omega_1^{L[r]} = \omega_1$.
This gives us the following:
\begin{proposition}
Assume ${\textrm{ZF}} + {\textrm{DC}} + \Phi(\omega_1, \omega_1, \omega)$.
Then
prevtext:
and we are done.
\end{proof}

\begin{lemma}(${\textrm{ZF}}$)
There is a function $f : \omega_1 \times {\mathbb}{R} \to \omega$
 such that

$$(\forall X \in [\omega_1]^\omega)
   (\exists y \in {\mathbb}{R})\,
   f`` X \times \{y\} \mbox{ is unbounded}.$$

 for each $X \in [\omega_1]^\omega$ and
 $g : X \to \omega$,

Given any $r \in {\mathbb}{R}$,

 \in {^\omega {\mathbb}{R}} \times {^\omega \omega}$
 be the $(\omega+\omega)$-sequence of
 reals and natural numbers canonically coded by $r$.

If $\eta(x) = \alpha$, say that $x$ is a \textit{code} for $\alpha$.
Define $f$ as follows:
 let $f(\alpha,r) := y^r_n$ if $x^r_n$ is a code for $\alpha$
 and no $x^r_m$ for $m < n$ is a code for $\alpha$,
 and let $f(\alpha,r) := 0$ if there is no such $x^r_n$.
The function $f$ is as desired:
 given $\{x_0, ...\} \in [\omega_1]^\omega$
 and $g : X \to \omega$,
 simply choose $r \in {\mathbb}{R}$ so that
 $(\forall n \in \omega)\, x^r_n = x_n$ and $y^r_n = g(x_n)$.

\begin{cor}
(ZF) $\neg \Phi( \omega_1, {\mathbb}{R}, \omega )$,
 and therefore also
 $\neg \Phi( {\mathbb}{R}, {\mathbb}{R}, \omega )$.
\end{cor}

Here is another way to get an $f$
 satisfying the hypothesis of Lemma~\ref{ideal_lemma}:
\begin{lemma}
\label{almost_disjoint_family}
(${\textrm{ZFC}}$)
There is a function $f : \omega_1 \times \omega_1 \to \omega$
 such that for each $\{x_1, x_2\} \in [\omega_1]^2$,
 $\{ \alpha < \omega_1 : f(x_1,\alpha) = f(x_2,\alpha)\}$
 has size $< \omega_1$.
That is, the collection of functions of the form
 $y \mapsto f(x,y)$ is an almost disjoint family.
\end{lemma}
\begin{proof}
For each $\alpha < \omega_1$, define the values
 $f(\beta, \alpha) : \beta < \alpha$ to be distinct by
 choosing a bijection from $\omega$ to $\alpha$.
The values $f(\beta,\alpha)$ for $\beta \ge \alpha$
 can be chosen to be anything.
\end{proof}

We now have the following:
\begin{cor}
(${\textrm{ZFC}}$)
$\Phi(\omega_1, \omega_1, \omega)$ is false.
\end{cor}
\begin{proof}
Use the function $f$ from Lemma~\ref{almost_disjoint_family}.
For each $X \in [\omega_1]^\omega$,

Therefore for each $X \in [\omega_1]^{\omega_1}$,
 ${\mathcal}{F}_X$ is unbounded.
The collection $[\omega_1]^{\omega_1}$ is the same thing

 ideal $[\omega_1]^\omega$ on $\omega_1$.
Thus, we may use
Lemma~\ref{ideal_lemma} with $f$ and ${\mathcal}{I}$.

\section{Lowerbound}

Note that Lemma~\ref{almost_disjoint_family} is satisfied
 in ${\textrm{ZF}}$ if there is a function
 $f : \omega_1 \to {\mathcal{P}}(\omega)$ that maps each
 $\alpha < \omega_1$ to a code $f(\alpha)$ for
 a well-ordering of ordertype $\alpha$.
This happens, for example,
 if there is an $r \in {\mathbb}{R}$ such that
 $\omega_1^{L[r]} = \omega_1$.
This gives us the following:
\begin{proposition}
Assume ${\textrm{ZF}} + {\textrm{DC}} + \Phi(\omega_1, \omega_1, \omega)$.
Then
text:
$$(\forall r \in {\mathbb}{R})\,
 \omega_1 \mbox{ is strongly inaccessible in } L[r].$$

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex6.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="(\forall r\in{\mathbb{}}{R})\,\omega_{1}\mbox{ is strongly inaccessible in }L[%
r]." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mo>∀</mo><mi>r</mi><mo>∈</mo><mi>R</mi><mo rspace="4.2pt" stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><msub><mi>ω</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mtext> is strongly inaccessible in </mtext><mi>L</mi><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mi>r</mi><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext:
It is well known that ${\textrm{ZF}} + {\textrm{DC}}$ implies that
 $\omega_1$ is regular
 (see Theorem 11.6 in \cite{Kanamori}).
By Proposition 11.5 of \cite{Kanamori},
\begin{eqnarray*}
 &&
 \omega_1 \mbox{ regular and }
 (\forall r \in {\mathbb}{R})\,
 \omega_1^{L[r]} < \omega_1 \\
 & \Rightarrow &
 (\forall r \in {\mathbb}{R})\,
 \omega_1 \mbox{ is strongly inaccessible in } L[r].
\end{eqnarray*}
This completes the proof.
\end{proof}

\section{Results in AD}

In the following, we really only use
 the fact that $r^\sharp$ exists for each $r \in {\mathbb}{R}$
 and that each $A \subseteq \omega_1$ is in some
 $L[r]$.






\begin{proposition}
(${\textrm{ZF}} + {\textrm{AD}}$)
$\Phi(\omega_1, \omega_1, \omega)$ is true.
\end{proposition}
\begin{proof}
Let $f : \omega_1 \times \omega_1 \to \omega$.
By Solovay's coding lemma
 (see \cite{Kleinberg}), let $r \in {\mathbb}{R}$
 be such that
 $f \in L[r]$.
Let ${\mathcal}{I} \subseteq \omega_1$ be the club of
 Silver indiscernibles for $L[r]$.
Let $a_1, ..., a_n \in {\mathcal}{I}$ be the indiscernibles
 used in the definition of $f$ in $L[r]$.
That is, there is a Skolem term $t$ such that
 $t(a_1, ..., a_n)^{L[r]} = f$.
Given any $\alpha < \omega_1$, let
 $C_\alpha := (b^\alpha_1, ..., b^\alpha_{m_\alpha},
   c^\alpha_1, ..., c^\alpha_{k_\alpha},
   t)$
 be a sequence of indiscernibles and a Skolem term such that
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex7.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="(\forall r\in{\mathbb{}}{R})\,\omega_{1}^{L[r]}<\omega_{1}." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mo>∀</mo><mi>r</mi><mo>∈</mo><mi>R</mi><mo rspace="4.2pt" stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><msubsup><mi>ω</mi><mn>1</mn><mrow><mi>L</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mi>r</mi><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow></mrow></msubsup><mo><</mo><msub><mi>ω</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

prevtext:
It is well known that ${\textrm{ZF}} + {\textrm{DC}}$ implies that
 $\omega_1$ is regular
 (see Theorem 11.6 in \cite{Kanamori}).
By Proposition 11.5 of \cite{Kanamori},
\begin{eqnarray*}
 &&
 \omega_1 \mbox{ regular and }
 (\forall r \in {\mathbb}{R})\,
 \omega_1^{L[r]} < \omega_1 \\
 & \Rightarrow &
 (\forall r \in {\mathbb}{R})\,
 \omega_1 \mbox{ is strongly inaccessible in } L[r].
\end{eqnarray*}
This completes the proof.
\end{proof}

\section{Results in AD}

In the following, we really only use
 the fact that $r^\sharp$ exists for each $r \in {\mathbb}{R}$
 and that each $A \subseteq \omega_1$ is in some
 $L[r]$.






\begin{proposition}
(${\textrm{ZF}} + {\textrm{AD}}$)
$\Phi(\omega_1, \omega_1, \omega)$ is true.
\end{proposition}
\begin{proof}
Let $f : \omega_1 \times \omega_1 \to \omega$.
By Solovay's coding lemma
 (see \cite{Kleinberg}), let $r \in {\mathbb}{R}$
 be such that
 $f \in L[r]$.
Let ${\mathcal}{I} \subseteq \omega_1$ be the club of
 Silver indiscernibles for $L[r]$.
Let $a_1, ..., a_n \in {\mathcal}{I}$ be the indiscernibles
 used in the definition of $f$ in $L[r]$.
That is, there is a Skolem term $t$ such that
 $t(a_1, ..., a_n)^{L[r]} = f$.
Given any $\alpha < \omega_1$, let
 $C_\alpha := (b^\alpha_1, ..., b^\alpha_{m_\alpha},
   c^\alpha_1, ..., c^\alpha_{k_\alpha},
   t)$
 be a sequence of indiscernibles and a Skolem term such that

nexttext:
We will replace $f$ with a function $f'$ such that
 $f \le f'$ and each value $f'(\alpha_1, \alpha_2)$
 only depends on the pair
 $(C_{\alpha_1}, C_{\alpha_2})$ and not on the pair
 $(\alpha_1, \alpha_2)$.
The value of $f(\alpha_1, \alpha_2)$,
 since it is a natural number, depends only on
 the Skolem term for $\alpha_1$,
 the Skolem term for $\alpha_2$,
 and the relative ordering of the ordinals in
 $C_{\alpha_1}$ and $C_{\alpha_2}$ with each other
 and with $a_1, ..., a_n$.
For fixed $C_{\alpha_1}$ and $C_{\alpha_2}$
 there are only finitely many such orderings,
 and so only finitely many possible values
 of $f(\alpha_1,\alpha_2)$ (only knowing
 $C_{\alpha_1}$ and $C_{\alpha_2}$).

Define $f'(\alpha_1,\alpha_2)$ to be the
 maximum of these possible values.
Given $\alpha$ and $\beta$, write
 $C_\alpha \simeq C_\beta$ if
 the Skolem term of $C_\alpha$ equals
 the Skolem term of $C_\beta$,
 the number of ordinals in $C_\alpha$
 less than $\alpha$ equals the number of
 ordinals in $C_\beta$ less than $\beta$,
 and similarly for the ordinals in $C_\alpha$
 greater than $\alpha$ and the ordinals in
 $C_\beta$ greater than $\beta$.
By the way $f'$ is defined,
 if  $C_{\alpha_1} \simeq C_{\beta_1}$
 and $C_{\alpha_2} \simeq C_{\beta_2}$, then
 $f'(\alpha_1, \alpha_2) =
  f'(\beta_1, \beta_2)$.
Up to $\simeq$, there are only countably many
 possible values of $C_\alpha$.
Thus $f'$,
 although technically a function from
 $\omega_1 \times \omega_1$ to $\omega$,
 can be viewed as a function from
 $\omega \times \omega$ to $\omega$.
Call that function
 $f'' : \omega \times \omega \to \omega$
 (we correspond natural numbers with $\simeq$ classes).
There certainly exist functions
 $g''_1, g''_2 : \omega \to \omega$ such that

These functions induce functions
 $g_1, g_2 : \omega_1 \to \omega$ such that
